clinical_study.brief_title: Early Child Care and Risk of Obesity
clinical_study.official_title: Nurture: Early Child Care and Risk of Obesity

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine risk factors associated with infant growth and the development of obesity in the first year of life. The investigators plan to establish a racially and ethnically diverse southern cohort of 800 mother/infant dyads, followed regularly from birth to 12 months of age. The cohort will be residents of Durham, North Carolina (NC) and the immediate surrounding area. The proposed longitudinal study will examine factors contributing to the development of obesity, including dietary behaviors, physical activity and inactivity, stress, and sleep duration and quality. Frequent in-home assessments throughout infancy and contact with other care providers will help pinpoint exactly when children begin to gain weight excessively and will identify risk factors related to energy intake, energy expenditure, stress, and sleep associated with obesity.

primary_outcome.description: In-person assessments of infant weight, length, and skinfold thicknesses at birth, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months of age

study_pop.textblock: Mothers/infant dyads in the Durham, NC area

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- mother over 18
- in 2nd or 3rd trimester of pregnancy with singleton
- speak and read English
- planning to stay in area for the first year of baby's life
Exclusion Criteria:
- baby born with conditions that may affect weight, feeding or motor activity
